artist: John Kilby Green; Publisher: John Redington
creditline: Gift of Marcia Wilcox Leslie O'Hagen, in loving memory of her grandmother, Frances Jones Leslie, daughter of Herschel V. Jones
medium: Etching with hand coloring on paper
text: In 19th-century London, toy theaters were printed paper models that could be cut out and assembled by home, a sort of cross between a dollhouse and a puppet show. One could buy the theater itself, then accessories such as sets, cutout figures, and scripts. Offering a consuming form of entertainment, it encouraged children to learn lines, cut out and decorate the figures, and stage performances for family and friends. This is a stage set from a version of The Tales of Baron Munchausen, rollicking tall tales first written by Rudolf Erich Raspe (1736–1794) but added to by many authors for decades after his death. This backdrop is self-referential in that the shop depicted sells toy theaters, one of which hangs on the facade above the windows, plus all the goods to go with them.
title: Redington's Scenes in Baron Munchausen, No. 8
